Description: Temptation of St Antony; the saint seated at l, surrounded by beasts, a nude woman crouched on a frog and holding a snake at r Oil, over charcoal (?)
Curator's comments: For an introduction to the series of St Antony, see under no. 1907-7-17-42. The saint is here again on the left hand side of the composition, seated with his back to his stone table (see also nos. 1907-7-17-52, 58, 66, 69 and 71) The only human figure is the female nude on the right foreground, crouching over a frog and holding a snake in her right hand. The snake could be a reference to Envy, while the frog is sometimes associated with Lust or Gluttony. 1907-7-17-1 to 90 is a so-called sketchbook, dismembered after its acquisition in 1907. A Title Page inscribed in brown ink is at the beginning of the series. Lit.: H. Tietze and E. Tietze-Conrat, 'The Drawings of the Venetian Painters in the 15th and 16th Centuries', New York, 1944, no. 1526/68, p. 265
Associated names: Representation of: St Antony of Egypt
Previous owner: Previous owner/ex-collection: Don Gaspar Mendez de Haro y Guzmán, Marchese del Carpio
Acquisition notes: 1907,0717.1 to 90 have been extracted from a XVIIc album with the title 'Disegni di Giacomo Tintoretto raccolti in Roma dall'Eccmo Sig. Don Gasparo d'Haro e Guzman, Marchese del Carpio .... e nel 1682 eletto Vice Re e Capitano Gnle del Regno di Napoli.' The album covers survive and are kept in the Stationary Cupboard.
